Broadcaster Steve Hewlett, who shared the story of his cancer battle on BBC Radio 4, has died aged 58. 
The tragedy comes after Mr Hewlett married his partner Rachel in hospital when doctors told him he had just "weeks, possibly months" to live. 
His battle against cancer of the oesophagus was documented in interviews with presenter Eddie Mair. 
His family said in a statement: "Over the last year, we have been overwhelmed by the support of friends, colleagues and Radio 4 listeners. Mr Hewlett married his partner after being told he had just weeks to live 
"The messages helped Steve enormously, especially over the last few months." 
BBC director general Tony Hall added: "Steve Hewlett was an exceptional journalist. His analysis of the media industry was always essential listening. He was in charge of BBC Panorama when it broadcast its controversial interview with Princess Diana (Photo: BBC) 
"Steve was a trusted voice that embodied everything positive in public service journalism. He was hugely popular not just with viewers and listeners, but with BBC staff. 
"When I saw him last week, I told him how much I have admired his brave interviews with Eddie Mair about his treatment which he did with a candour and sense of inquiry that was typically Steve." Like us on Facebook
